messages.content:
I'm struggling to fully understand recursion. While I'm following along with this rollup example https://github.com/es92/zkApp-examples/blob/main/09-recursion/src/rollup.ts to generate a proof from the provided transitions, I am struggling to understand what provides assurances to the correctness of the input data.

For example, I can generate a valid proof using this example by only processing 3 of these transitions, and once this proof is committed to chain I have no way to know the input data used, only that the proof is valid?

Am I correct in understanding that the recursion step provides guarantees via a proof that the input data was processed according to the provided program but says nothing about the correctness of the input data used? In this example case, we would essentially be trusting the rollup provider to provide these transitions - in a real system these transitions would actually be committed to on-chain, say via a merkle tree root hash, and that's how we provide guarantees on the input data?

The reason I am thinking about this is I'd like to verify multiple signatures in a ZkProgram and only pass in a single valid proof to the zkApp that essentially says "I have validated all these signatures and they are correct". My issue is I can conceptually see how I can rollup these proofs by merging them together, but can't understand how to prove I have actually processed **all** signatures and not just a subset (as in both cases I get a valid proof). If I understand correctly, I think I need to commit to *something* (on-chain presumably) and simply completing the rollup isn't enough. Real example signatures here, imagine I want to prove I have validated all 5 signatures from a zkProgram, is this possible? https://gist.github.com/garethtdavies/4e976db974c05a77930e447155046b3f

Yes, thanks! I think I am starting to get it. So now I get how I would prove the correct keys are being used. I presumably would also need some form of constraint to ensure that every signature was run once and only once.
Yea ideally you would have to keep track to avoid duplicate signatures/actions
Yeh that makes sense. Will try to make a toy example just for the rolling up of verification of signatures as a starting point before trying to tackle anything more 🙂
You could serialise signatures and add a nonce to each, then a public state that keeps track of the current nonce
And just increment the public state nonce with every verified signature
very basic but good enough for the start
Awesome, thanks for the help, this gets me started for sure and can ask more specific questions down the road 🙏🏼
